**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2025-06-05

**KEY CONTENT**:
- President Yoweri Museveni officially launched Fourth National Development Plan (NDP IV)
- Kololo Ceremonial Grounds, June 5, 2025
- Period: FY 2025/26 to FY 2029/30 (5 years)

#### DOCUMENT UG-POL-003
**SOURCE_URL**: https://statehouse.go.ug/state-of-the-nation-address-2025-by-president-yoweri-kaguta-museveni/
**COUNTRY**: Uganda
**CATEGORY**: Political
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: State of Nation Address
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2025

**KEY CONTENT**:
- President Museveni State of Nation Address 2025
- Economy more diversified and sophisticated vs 1986
- Harvard Economic Growth Lab study: Last 10 years, Uganda added 20 new products to export basket
- Opportunity to harness 50 new complex products
- GDP per capita: USD 1,263 (growing 6.3% annually)
- Projected 7% growth 2025/26
- "Irreversibly a middle-income country"
- Uganda Vision 2040 progress
- President implored MPs to mobilize Ugandans for wealth creation initiatives

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Strong messaging on "irreversibly middle-income" status. 6.3-7% growth is excellent. Diversifying export basket suggests growing SME sector (key MFI target market). Presidential emphasis on wealth creation creates political backing for financial inclusion.

#### DOCUMENT UG-POL-004
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.finance.go.ug/sites/default/files/2025-06/Budget%20Speech%20FY2025%20web_0.pdf
**COUNTRY**: Uganda
**CATEGORY**: Political/Fiscal
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Budget Speech
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2025-06

**KEY CONTENT**:
- Budget Speech FY 2025/26
- Economy size: USD 61B (exchange rate method), USD 174B (purchasing power parity)
- Population: ~45 million
- No longer least developed country
- Lower middle-income country status
- Continued focus on industrialization, agriculture, infrastructure

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Economy USD 61B is larger than Kenya (USD 53B in same year). PPP of USD 174B shows strong domestic purchasing power. Lower middle-income status means growing consumer finance demand.

#### DOCUMENT UG-POL-005
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.pulse.ug/story/time-to-get-uganda-out-of-financial-stone-age-says-bou-governor-2025112510264680208
**COUNTRY**: Uganda
**CATEGORY**: Political/Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Governor Speech
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2025-11-25

**KEY CONTENT**:
- BOU Governor Dr Michael Atingi-Ego keynote at 3rd Kampala Blockchain Summit
- "Time to get Uganda out of financial stone age"
- Government determined to roll out comprehensive regulatory framework for Blockchain industry
- Uganda at crossroads: Lead Africa's digital financial transformation or trail behind
- Quote: "We are living in a time when a month in digital innovation can alter the entire business model. Tech once considered theoretical such as tokenised securities, and blockchain cross border payments are now operating in advanced markets."
- "We need to get Uganda out of the financial stone age."
- Atingi-Ego appointed Governor February 2025 after acting for 2 years following Governor Mutebile's death (January 2022)
- Positive ratings for steering CBin midst of tough times: Slow COVID recovery, rapid monetary expansion, fiscal indiscipline, corruption scandals
- PhD from Liverpool University (1996), IMF African Department Deputy Director (2008), started at BOU 1984

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Governor Atingi-Ego is VERY pro-innovation and pro-fintech. "Financial stone age" comment is striking - shows frustration with slow digital adoption. Blockchain framework signals openness to cutting-edge technology. This is a fintech-friendly regulator.

### SECTION 2: TAX & FISCAL POLICY (3 Documents)

#### DOCUMENT UG-TAX-001
**SOURCE_URL**: https://ura.go.ug/en/download/tax-amendments-2024-25/
**COUNTRY**: Uganda
**CATEGORY**: Tax
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Tax Legislation
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2024-07-15

**KEY CONTENT**:
- President assented 19 Bills into law July 15, 2024
- Including: Income Tax (Amendment) Bill 2024, VAT (Amendment) Bill 2024, Excise Duty (Amendment) Bill 2024, Tax Procedure Code (Amendment) Bill 2024, Stamp Duty (Amendment) Bill 2024
- Commencement: July 1, 2024
- FY 2024/25: No major tax rate changes proposed
- Revenue generation focus on URA compliance measures
- Enhanced enforcement

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Relatively stable tax environment for FY 2024/25. Focus on compliance rather than rate increases. However, 19 bills in one package suggests active tax law environment - need to monitor changes carefully.

#### DOCUMENT UG-TAX-002
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.rfilc.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/The-Impact-of-Mobile-Money-Taxation-in-Uganda.pdf
**COUNTRY**: Uganda
**CATEGORY**: Tax
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Research Report
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2021-11

**KEY CONTENT**:
- Excise Duty (Amendment) Act 2018 introduced:
  - Mobile Money Tax: 0.5% on withdrawals (effective 2018-19 FY)
  - OTT Tax: UGX 200 per day for social media apps (Facebook, Twitter, WhatsApp, etc.)
- Effective July 1, 2021: OTT 'social media' tax REMOVED, replaced with 12% tax on Internet data
- Total value of Mobile Money transactions peaked UGX 6.9T (2018), dropped ~UGX 1T after tax
- URA data: 1% mobile money tax contributed Ush 22B (USD 5.8M), Ush 200 daily social media tax contributed Ush 4.3B (USD 1.1M)
- March 2024 ICTD Policy Brief: Current mobile money tax system "widely disliked, unbalanced, arguably distortionary"

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Uganda experimented with controversial mobile money taxation (0.5% on withdrawals remains). This tax directly hits MFI customers who use mobile money. The OTT/social media tax replaced with 12% internet data tax also affects digital financial services. These taxes create friction in digital financial inclusion - policy advocacy opportunity for sector.

### SECTION 3: BOU REGULATIONS (4 Documents)

#### DOCUMENT UG-REG-001
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.bou.or.ug/bouwebsite/Supervision/actsandregulations.html
**COUNTRY**: Uganda
**CATEGORY**: Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Regulatory Framework
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2024

**KEY CONTENT**:
- BOU has mandate to supervise: Commercial Banks, Credit Institutions, Micro Finance Deposit-Taking Institutions (MDIs), Forex Bureaux
- Acts and Regulations governing supervision:
  - Micro Deposit Taking Institutions Act 2003
  - Tier 4 Microfinance Institutions Money Lenders Act 2016
  - Micro Finance Deposit-Taking Institutions (Revision of Minimum Capital Requirements) Instrument 2024
  - Micro-Finance Deposit-Taking Institutions Registered Societies Regulations 2023
- Non-Bank Financial Institutions department supervises: Credit Institutions, MDIs, Forex Bureaus, Money Remitters, NSSF, Deposit Protection Fund, Credit Reference Bureau

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Uganda has simpler regulatory structure than Kenya/Tanzania. Key distinction is MDI (Microfinance Deposit-Taking Institutions) vs Tier 4. 2024 capital requirement revision suggests consolidation pressure. Regulations from 2023 are recent - relatively modern framework.

#### DOCUMENT UG-REG-002
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.bou.or.ug/bouwebsite/bouwebsitecontent/Supervision/Micro-Finance-Deposit-Taking-Institutions-Registered-Societies-Regulations-2023.pdf
**COUNTRY**: Uganda
**CATEGORY**: Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Regulations
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2023

**KEY CONTENT**:
- Statutory Instrument 2023 No. 54
- Micro-Finance Deposit-Taking Institutions (Registered Societies) Regulations 2023
- Governs MDIs structured as registered societies
- Prudential requirements
- Governance standards
- Reporting obligations

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: 2023 regulations are very recent. MDI software must comply with these updated standards. Registered societies structure suggests cooperative/member-owned model.

**SOURCE_URL**: https://archive.bou.or.ug/bou/supervision/overview.html
**COUNTRY**: Uganda
**CATEGORY**: Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Supervisory Overview
**CERTAINTY**: medium

**KEY CONTENT**:
- BOU supervisory approach overview
- Risk-based supervision methodology

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Risk-based supervision means BOU focuses on higher-risk institutions. Software with strong risk management and early warning capabilities can help MDIs stay off BOU's watchlist.

**SOURCE_URL**: https://umra.go.ug/licensed-tier-4-microfinance-institutions-and-money-lenders-as-of-march-2022/
**COUNTRY**: Uganda
**CATEGORY**: Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Regulatory List
**CERTAINTY**: medium

**KEY CONTENT**:
- Uganda Microfinance Regulatory Authority (UMRA) regulates Tier 4 MFIs and Money Lenders
- List of licensed Tier 4 institutions as of March 2022
- Separate regulator from BOU (which regulates MDIs)

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Uganda has UMRA for Tier 4 (separate from BOU). This is unique in the region. Two regulators means potentially different software requirements for MDIs vs Tier 4 MFIs.

### SECTION 4: MFI SECTOR DATA (3 Documents)

#### DOCUMENT UG-DATA-001
**SOURCE_URL**: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_microfinance_deposit-taking_institutions_in_Uganda
**COUNTRY**: Uganda
**CATEGORY**: Sector Data
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Institution List
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2024-01-19

**KEY CONTENT**:
- As of January 19, 2024: 3 licensed MDIs
  1. FINCA Uganda Limited (MDI)
  2. PRIDE Microfinance Limited (MDI)
  3. UGAFODE Microfinance Limited (MDI)
- EFC Uganda Limited (EFCUL) license withdrawn and institution liquidated by BOU January 19, 2024
- All 3 MDIs licensed and regulated by Bank of Uganda

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Only 3 licensed MDIs - TINY market compared to Kenya (14) and Tanzania (4). But these 3 likely have significant scale. EFC Uganda liquidation shows BOU is willing to take strong supervisory action. Market concentration means sales strategy should focus on these 3 initially, then expand to Tier 4.

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Beyond the 3 MDIs, there are numerous Tier 4 MFIs (exact number unclear but likely dozens to hundreds based on UMRA list reference). This is a larger market opportunity than just the 3 MDIs suggest.

#### DOCUMENT RW-POL-001
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.paulkagame.rw/inclusive-fintech-forum-remarks-by-president-kagame-kigali-25-february-2025/
**COUNTRY**: Rwanda
**CATEGORY**: Political
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Presidential Speech
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2025-02-25

**KEY CONTENT**:
- President Paul Kagame keynote at Inclusive FinTech Forum 2025 (February 24-26, 2025, Kigali)
- Second edition of forum
- Key quote: "Indeed, with our continent's young and tech-savvy population, Africa can compete with the rest of the world and successfully innovate. When you look at our continent's startup ecosystem, fintechs continue to dominate."
- Rwanda made strategic investments in digital infrastructure and skills
- Number one priority: Creating enabling environment for businesses to scale
- Need for harmonized regulatory landscape
- Combat cybercrime and fraud
- Opportunities: Public-private partnerships, AI
- Quote: "Taking ownership of our development is not something we can ask others to do for us. Business founders must play their part and gain confidence of investors. Bottom line is we need to work as one team to build a more connected future."
- Commended Kigali International Financial Center (KIFC) for positioning Rwanda as attractive investment destination
- Partnership between Rwanda and Singapore on digital economy
- Challenges highlighted: Brain drain of skilled developers, women financial inclusion in informal economy
- National Fintech Strategy 2024-2029: Target 80% fintech adoption by 2029
- Fintech startups: 17 (2014) â†’ 80+ (2024) - nearly TRIPLED in 10 years
- Goal: 7,500 jobs from fintech

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: President Kagame is PERSONALLY championing fintech. This is TOP-LEVEL political backing. Rwanda-Singapore partnership brings world-class expertise. 80% fintech adoption by 2029 target is extremely ambitious. Nearly tripling of fintech startups shows momentum. 7,500 jobs target suggests significant ecosystem development funding.
